channel.title: New question: Setting Up Kate?
channel.description:
Well, here's a little question; I've searched, but how do you get flash on a 64 bit architecture?
Seeing as Adobe don't make it for 64 yet :(
Well, you know on Windows how you can create a batch file, with javac *.java, etc. What, and how do you do something similar in Linux. I'm sick of opening Shell to compile every time.
[size=20pt]-All solved above here, read below here-[/size]
Well, I've seen people set Kate up so you can compile, + run your java files. I did a google search and lead to [url=http://here[http://www.tuxmachines.org/index.php?q=node/13762]]here[http://www.tuxmachines.org/index.php?q=node/13762][/url] My code that I used to make an External Tool in Kate looks like this; [code]cd "%directory" && konsole -e sh -c 'javac "%filename"; printf "%s" "Press any key to exit . . . "; read $dummy'[/code] It does compile fine, runs the command, etc. But it closes at the end. Konsole opens up, compiles it, and closes straight away. If it threw me an error I wouldn't be able to read it, same with running it.
What I need is the command for what you would run on windows - pause - in that script I believe.
Anyway, thanks in advance.

item.title: New question: Setting Up Kate?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Being able to do it with Kate would be awesome though.

Read full topic

item.title: New question: Setting Up Kate?
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

What you would do is, first create a symlink in /bin/ for java and javac (if it’s not there already), then as Kmb said, make a shell script, stick that in there, and chmod a+x it.

Read full topic

item.description:

Ohk, thanks Travis
Just foolin’ with ya. Thanks.[br][size=1]Posted on: October 03, 2007, 04:13:50 PM[/size][hr]Hmm, you can’t use pause, lel.

@Yz85Racer wrote:

Yeah, thanks Kmb, but, is there special permisions I need to set it? I’ve made it executable, but I need to run it in terminal, sh compile.sh. Etc.[br][size=1]Posted on: October 02, 2007, 08:51:43 PM[/size][hr]Okay, got a new question. Check first post.

Read full topic

item.title: New question: Setting Up Kate?
item.dc:creator: @kmb Kmb
item.description:
@kmb wrote:

#!/bin/bash javac *.java

Read full topic

item.title: New question: Setting Up Kate?

So, what command and what script would I use?

item.title: New question: Setting Up Kate?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Yes, you want to execute ‘javac *.java’ in the directory where all of your .java files are, not just in linux, but on any platform.

Read full topic

item.title: New question: Setting Up Kate?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:14, topic:148278”]Yup. I’ve got JDK installed. I know, it’s weird, here’s what I have in my shell script.
#!/bin/bash
cd /home/kyle/java-6-sun-1.6.0.00/bin
javac *.java[/quote]

No no no, that’s moving the current directory to /home/kyle/java-6-sun-1.6.0.00/bin, so your doing javac *.java in java-6-sun-1.6.0.00/bin.

Read full topic

javac *.java

item.title: New question: Setting Up Kate?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

There is supposedly a program to wrap 32-bit plugins for a 64-bit browser, it may be called something like nspluginwrapper or something. However when I tried this about 6 months ago it flat out didn’t work, and I ended up installing a 32-bit firefox along with all of the relevant flash/java plugins in addition to my 64-bit firefox. There are tutorials for both out there on the web, tell us what you do and how it ends up working please.

Read full topic
